column1: {{quote|Friendship with the latter marked the breakdown of two old prejudices. At my first coming into the world I had been (implicitly) warned never to trust a Papist
column2: and at my first coming into the English Faculty (explicitly) never to trust a philologist. Tolkien was both.|C.S. Lewis

column5: was an Irish-born English writer and scholar. Lewis is known for his work on medieval literature
column8: and fiction. He is best known today for his series ''[[The Chronicles of Narnia]]''.

column1: Lewis was a close friend of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]. Both authors were leading figures in the English faculty at [[Oxford University]] and in the informal Oxford literary group known as the [[Inklings]]. According to his memoir ''[[Surprised by Joy]]''
column2: Lewis had been baptised in the Church of Ireland at birth
column3: but fell away from his faith during his adolescence. Owing to the influence of Tolkien and other friends
column6: becoming "a very ordinary layman of the Church of England". His conversion had a profound effect on his work
column7: and his wartime radio broadcasts on the subject of Christianity brought him wide acclaim.

column1: Tolkien noted that some of his onomatopoeia influenced names in Lewis' works
column3: [[Eldar|Eldil]] (''Out of the Silent Planet'') and [[Tuor|Tur]] and [[Idril|Tinidril]] (''Perelandra'').<ref>{{L|276}}</ref>
